sections.text: Witr is the last prayer of the night. It was strongly encouraged by the Prophet (ﷺ) and done by him regularly even during travels. Witr refers to the single rak‘ah which concludes the voluntary night prayers so that they become an odd number.
It can be performed any time after ‘isha’ prayer up until fajr.

One may pray two rak‘ahs at a time followed by the single rak‘ah.
Or all rak‘ahs can be prayed continuously, with julūs only at the end of the final rak‘ah.
Or with julūs and salam in the next-to-last rak‘ah, followed by the single rak‘ah. All of these forms were related in authentic hadiths.
Witr is commonly prayed as three rak‘ahs.

items: After al-Fātiḥah in the 1st rak‘ah: Sūrah al-A‘lā (87)
After al-Fātiḥah in the 2nd rak‘ah: Sūrah al-Kāfirūn (109)
After al-Fātiḥah in the 3rd rak‘ah: Sūrah al-Ikhlāṣ (112)

sections.text: (Any other portions of the Qur’ān are also acceptable.)

اللهم اهدِنا فيمَن هديت .. وعافنا فيمن عافيت .. وتولنا فيمن توليت ..
وبارك لنا فيما أعطيت .. وقِنا شر ما قضيت .. انك تقضي ولا يقضى عليك ..
انه لا يذل مَن واليت .. ولا يعز من عاديت .. تباركت ربنا وتعاليت ..
لك الحمد على ما قضيت .. ولك الشكر على ما أعطيت ..
نستغفرك اللهم من جميع الذنوب والخطايا ونتوب إليك.

“O Allah, guide me among those You have guided, grant me well-being among those You have granted it, choose me among those You have chosen, bless for me what You have given, and protect me from the evil of what You have decreed—for You decree and nothing is decreed over You. He whom You ally is never humiliated, and he whom You oppose is never honored. Blessed are You, our Lord, and Exalted. We ask Your forgiveness, O Allah, for all sins and turn in repentance to You. And may Allah’s blessings be upon the Prophet Muhammad.”
Narrated by Aḥmad, Abū Dāwūd and at-Tirmidhī, who graded it ḥasan and said, “Nothing is known about qunut from the Prophet (ﷺ) more authentic than this.”
